msDesc.head: Guido of Arezzo and Bede on music

supportDesc.support: both on vellum (the first HSOS/HFFH, the second FSOS/FHHF).
supportDesc.extent: Fols. vii + 44 (numbered fols. 1–42, viii, ix) + v (numbered fols. x–xiv). 216 115

binding.p: A modern replacement. Sewn on five thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf, two modern paper flyleaves, four medieval vellum flyleaves (the first a former pastedown, with a College bookplate on the verso); at the rear, two medieval vellum flyleaves (the second a former pastedown), two modern paper leaves, and another marbled leaf (x–xiv).

provenance.p: ‘Iste liber est Fratris Iohannis de Erghom in quo subscript’ continentur Musica F’ (fol. viiv). The volume was ‘Arsmetrica Musica Geometria Perspectiua magistri Johannis Erghome’ F’ in the 1372 catalogue of the York Austin friars, ed. K. W. Humphreys, CBMLC, 1:153 (A 8.643) (Ker, MLGB 218, 321); the catalogue entry is generally equivalent to the list of contents on fol. viiv (indicated by the ellipses above):
a Musica Gydonis in prosa; b musica eiusdem in metro; c musica cuiusdam sub dialogo; d liber Bede de arte metrica; e item liber eiusdem de tropis’.

history.provenance: ‘Kat’ wilstrop vj s viij d Robert Percy militis v s x d Percyvdll lyndlay vj s viij d farbarn’ xx d Thikhed Domina beatrix thorneff priorissa Domina Alicia thornton Domina katerina Brokhellis Domina maria Foston Domina Margareta Wistow Domina Iohanna home Domina alicia Newton Domina Isabella child’ (fol. ix; s. xv ex., secretary). The nuns are apparently those of Thicket (E. Yks., OSB).
The old shelfmark ‘Abac: ij. N. 50’ (fol. vv).

msItem.rubric: In nomine summe et indiuidue trinitatis incipit micrologus id est breuis sermo in musica uersus sequentis operis
Epistola GUIDONIS ad teodaldum aretine ciuitatis episcopum
msItem.incipit: Diuini timoris totiusque prudentię fulgore clarissimo dulcissimo patri

Cvm me et naturalis conditio et bonorum immitatio communis utilitatis diligentem [corr. from –er]
[the text] Quid faciat qui se ad disciplinam parat Igitur qui nostram disciplinam petit aliquantos cantus nostris notis descriptos
msItem.explicit: semper humanas tenebras illustrante cuius suma sapientia per cuncta uiget secula
msItem.author: GUIDO OF AREZZO
msItem.title: Micrologus
msItem.note: ed. Jos. Smits van Waesberghe, Corpus scriptorum de musica 4 (1955) 46–233, with a description of our MS at 44.

msItem.rubric: Gliscunt corda meis hominum mollita camenis Ordine me scripsi primo qui carna finxi |
msItem.incipit: Mvsicorvm et cantorum magna est distantia | Isti dicunt illi sciunt que componit musica
msItem.explicit: Auctor indiget et scriptor gloria sit domino amen | Omnibus ecce modilis descripta relatio uocis
msItem.note: ‘Musica eiusdem in metro’ (the contents table, fol. viiv), i.e. GUIDO, Regulae rhythmicae, ed. Martin Gerbert, Scriptores ecclesiastici de musica (St Blasien, 1784; rept. [Milan, 1931]) 2:25–33.

msItem.incipit: Temporibus nostris super omnes homines fatui sunt cantores In omni enim arte ualde plura sunt
msItem.explicit: in ipsa neumarum figura monstratur si sicut debent ex industria componantur
msItem.author: GUIDO OF AREZZO
msItem.title: ‘Praefatio in antiphonarium’

msItem.incipit: Beatissimo atque dulcissimo fratri M G per anfractus multos deiectus et actus Aut dura sunt tempora aut diuinę dispositionis obscura discriminandum
msItem.explicit: omnia cum uix litteris ut cumque significemus facili tantum colloquio denudamus
msItem.incipit: Qvi uero monocordium desiderat et qualitates et quantitates similitudines
msItem.explicit: Cuius liber non cantoribus sed solis philosophis utilis est
msItem.note: ‘Musica cuiusdam sub dialago’ (the contents table), i.e. GUIDO, Regule de ignotu cantu or ‘Epistola Michaeli monacho’, ed. Gerbert, 2:43–50. The break at fol. 22 is followed by a musical gamut, perhaps the beginning of item 4.

msItem.incipit: [marg., anglicana, s. xiv ex.] Nota prologus in istum tractatum incipit peti is obnixe fieris Quid est musica Magister ueraciter canendi sciencia et facilis uia ad perfectionem canendi
msItem.explicit: elationi inseruiens minus iam subditus creatori qui est benedictus in secula seculorum amen
msItem.note: The so-called ‘Dialogus ODDONIS de musica’, ed. Gerbert, 1:252–64 (the prologue missing here at 251). Michel Huglo, ‘L’auteur du “Dialogue sur la musique” attribue à Odon’, Revue de musicologie 55 (1969), 119–71 demonstrates that the work is in fact from Lombardy, and written c.1000 (Odo of Cluny, d. 942). Huglo discovered our copy intercalated into item 4 (see 125).

msItem.incipit: Ad iudicium primi toni hec antiphona ponitur Moxerum ut cum fine alicuius antiphonę
msItem.explicit: uocamus acutas Septem autem litterę dupliciter designantur hoc modo sed dissimiliter
msItem.note: A tonarium from central Italy, replacing the Odonian work which usually follows item 5; other copies appear at Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS CLM 14523, fols. 132–3v; Rome, Biblioteca Vallicellana MS B.81, fol. 128. Followed by a musical scale, and a diagram of notes.

msItem.incipit: Dic mihi quot formę sunt can[quan]tus queso magister
msItem.explicit: Quę minor his fuerit non cantus at oda uocatur
msItem.note: Six verses (perhaps associable with Walther, no. 4369). Fol. 24v is blank.

supportDesc.collation: 18 (4 and 5 singles) 28 38 (4 and 5 singles). No catchwords or signatures.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in long lines, 38 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in stylus.

handDesc.handNote: Written in caroline, s. xi/xii; the localization depends on the use of ‘Aquitanian’ notation in some of the musical settings. Punctuation by point, medial point, high point, and occasional punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Headings usually in red (some in green), a few in rustic capitals.
Two-line red arabesque initials slashed in green at the heads of the texts.
Diagrams in text ink, with red and green decoration.
See AT, no. 641 (64) (fols. 1–24 only; dated s. xi2).

msItem.incipit: Me lege si linguam cupias cognoscere bede Qui noticiam metrice artis habere desiderat primo necesse est vt distanciam
msItem.explicit: ut lectioni operam impendas illarum maxime litterarum in quibus nos uitam habere credimus sempiternam
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit de arte metrica liber primus [later rubric]
msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De arte metrica
msItem.note: CPL 1565, ed. C. B. Kendall, CC 123A 82–141. A contents table between the introduction and the text.

msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de scematibus et tropis
msItem.incipit: Solet aliquociens in scripturis ordo uerborum causa doctoris aliter quam uulgaris uia dicendi
msItem.explicit: ne descendat tollere illa et qui in agro similiter non reddat retro memoris loth
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber uenerabilis BEDE presbiteri de scematibus et tropis [later rubric]
msItem.note: CPL 1567, in fact part 2 of the preceding text, ed. Kendall, 142–71. Fols. viii and ixrv are bounded and ruled, but blank; fol. viiiv is blank and unruled.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 33–5 lines to the page. Prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink

handDesc.handNote: Written in textura quadrata, s. xiii ex. or xiii/xiv, a single hand, but differing decorative schemes for each text. Punctuation by point and medial point.

decoDesc.decoNote: Text 8 has headings in red, and three of the chapters are introduced by 2-line red lombards.
Elsewhere capitals are in text ink and ochre-slashed. Some extended top line ascenders, a few with heads or shrubs and ochre-slashed.
Text 9 has 2-line red lombards, unflourished, at textual divisions and occasional red paraphs to set off line run-over.
